journal-title-group.journal-title: European Journal of Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine

title-group.article-title: A connectome-based functional magnetic resonance imaging study of visuospatial analogical reasoning in stroke

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, School of Medicine, Fujita Health University, Toyoake, Japan; 2Section of Brain Function Information, National Institute for Physiological Sciences, Okazaki, Japan; 3Core for Spin Life Sciences, Okazaki Collaborative Platform, National Institutes of Natural Sciences, Okazaki, Japan

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Yohei Otaka, Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, School of Medicine, Fujita Health University, 1-98 Dengakugakubo, Kutsukake, Toyoake 470-1192, Japan. E-mail: otaka119@mac.com

fn.p: Authors’ contributions: Takamichi Tohyama contributed to the conceptualization of the study, the acquisition, analysis and interpretation of data, and writing the manuscript. Masaki Fukunaga contributed to the conceptualization of the study, the analysis and interpretation of data, and writing the manuscript; Yohei Otaka contributed to the conceptualization of the study, the management of data, and writing the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final version of the manuscript.

license.license-p: This is an open-access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives (CC BY-NC-ND) 4.0 License.

sec.title: BACKGROUND
sec.p: Visuospatial function is a core domain of functional cognition in stroke. Post-stroke cognitive impairment disrupts rehabilitation practice, highlighting the importance of characterizing patients with higher-order visuospatial dysfunction to inform personalized rehabilitation strategies. Although neuroimaging offers insights into disease-related mechanisms, its clinical application remains limited.

sec.title: AIM
sec.p: The aim of this paper was to investigate whether the residual resting-state functional connectivity supports higher-order visuospatial function after stroke and whether changes in connectivity can characterize patients with visuospatial dysfunction.

sec.title: DESIGN
sec.p: Observational study.

sec.title: SETTING
sec.p: Inpatient rehabilitation ward at Fujita Health University Hospital in Japan.

sec.title: POPULATION
sec.p: Fifty-eight patients with stroke.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: Visuospatial analogical reasoning was assessed using Raven’s Colored Progressive Matrices (RCPM). Resting-state functional connectivity was evaluated using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Empirical covariance matrices and group-sparse inverse covariance (GSIC) matrices were computed from the fMRI data, with the latter negated to estimate partial correlations representing direct connectivity. Correlations between connectivity measures and RCPM scores were analyzed, alongside data-driven clustering to stratify patients.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: No significant correlation was found between empirical covariance connectivity and RCPM scores. However, GSIC-based analysis revealed a significant inverse correlation between connectivity of the posteromedial and the left inferior parietal cortex and RCPM scores. Higher parietal connectivity was associated with lower RCPM performance. Patients in the highest connectivity cluster exhibited severe impairments in visuospatial analogical reasoning, particularly in tasks requiring the integration of discrete figures into spatially related wholes. The lesions in these patients were predominantly localized in the left subcortex.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Medio-lateral parietal connectivity may underlie visuospatial analogical reasoning after stroke.

sec.title: CLINICAL REHABILITATION IMPACT
sec.p: Clustering analysis highlighted a distinct pattern of low scores in patients with increased parietal connectivity, suggesting that parietal connectivity changes have the potential for characterizing patients with severe dysfunction.

body.p: Visuospatial function is a core domain of functional cognition in stroke.1 Post-stroke cognitive impairment frequently disrupts rehabilitation practice, highlighting the importance of characterizing higher-order visuospatial dysfunction for personalized rehabilitation planning. Although neuroimaging has provided valuable insights into the mechanisms underlying stroke-related dysfunction, its routine clinical use remains limited. Early studies using resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) connectivity2 have demonstrated that changes in functional connectivity may reflect focal symptoms of stroke.3, 4 However, it is unclear whether residual functional connectivity supports higher-order visuospatial function in patients with stroke or whether changes in connectivity can characterize patients with visuospatial dysfunction.

The Raven’s Colored Progressive Matrices (RCPM) is commonly used to assess intellectual performance in individuals with impaired cognitive activity, particularly their capacity for visuospatial analogical reasoning.5 Brain lesions are known to reduce RCPM scores,6, 7 and these reductions are influenced by lesion location.6, 7 However, determining the role of the residual connectivity in visuospatial analogical reasoning remains challenging due to the absence of assumptions about causal connectivity and the significant variability in lesion type and location among patients. Addressing these challenges requires advanced connectivity analyses using data-driven approaches to whole-brain networks.

In previous studies of fMRI connectivity mapping of post-stroke behavior, selection of targeted connectivity patterns was based on a priori assumptions.3, 4 This has biased connectivity mapping; if the non-targeted connectivity contributes to behavior, it may remain undetectable. However, advances in network modelling have enabled sophisticated analyses of resting-state fMRI data.8 These methods map whole-brain connectivity into a “functional connectome” by assessing connectivity between nodes based on their fMRI time series. Among these approaches, sparse inverse covariance estimation with ℓ1-norm regularization9 has shown high sensitivity for detecting network connections.10 Group-level studies benefit further from group-sparse inverse covariance (GSIC) estimation, which uses the regularization based on a mixed norm ℓ21 to extract a detailed model of individual-level brain connectivity from group data, by imposing a common sparsity structure across individuals.11

To identify neural substrates underlying higher-order visuospatial function and explore whether changes in functional connectivity can characterize patients with visuospatial dysfunction, we conducted a connectome-based fMRI study of visuospatial analogical reasoning in patients with stroke. This study employed GSIC-based network modelling and data-driven clustering to analyze the relationship between connectivity patterns and cognitive function.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: This cross-sectional observational study enrolled 73 patients with stroke admitted to inpatient rehabilitation ward at Fujita Health University Hospital, Toyoake, Japan. Fifteen patients were excluded: seven due to excessive movement during resting-state fMRI scans (see MRI data acquisition and analysis), four due to unsuccessful fMRI preprocessing, and four with incomplete RCPM test data. Data from 58 patients were ultimately analyzed. All patients underwent standard physiotherapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy, as needed. The mean age (SD) of the patients was 66.6 (14.1) years, with 37 males. Stroke types included hemorrhagic (N.=26) and ischemic (N.=32). Lesions were located on the right, left, and both sides in 24, 28, and 6 patients, respectively. Among these, seven had lesions in either the cerebellum (N.=1) or brainstem (N.=6). The mean time (SD) from stroke onset to assessment was 55 (43) days.

The study procedures were explained to all participants, and written informed consent was obtained in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Review Committee of Fujita Health University (Reference number: HM20-257, HM22-529).

sec.title: Behavioral assessments
sec.p: RCPM, consisting of three sets (A, Ab, and B; each with a range of 0-12),5 was administered during occupational therapy to assess higher-order cognitive processes.

sec.title: MRI data acquisition and analysis
sec.p: MRI scans were conducted using a 3T MR scanner (Vantage Centurian; Canon Medical Systems, Otawara, Japan) with a 32-channel head coil. Head positioning was stabilized with soft pads.

sec.title: Structural imaging
sec.p: Inversion recovery T1-weighted (T1W) whole-brain images were scanned using the 3D fast field echo sequence with the Advanced Intelligent Clear-IQ Engine technology (voxel size, 0.8×0.8×0.8 mm; repetition time [TR]/echo time [TE]/inversion time, 2500/2.7/900 ms; SPEEDER [phase direction × slice direction], 2×1.5; flip angle [FA], 8°; field of view [FOV], 240×240 mm). T2-weighted (T2W) whole-brain images were scanned using the 3D fast advanced spin echo-multiplanar voxel (voxel size, 0.8×0.8×0.8 mm; TR/TE, 3200/297.6 ms; echo spacing [ES], 4.8 ms; SPEEDER [phase direction × slice direction], 2×1.4; FOV, 240×240 mm).

sec.title: Functional imaging
sec.p: Blood oxygenation level-dependent (BOLD) signals were acquired using gradient-echo echo planar imaging (EPI): voxel size, 3.5×3.5×3.2 mm; slice gap, 0.3 mm; TR/TE, 2500/25 ms; ES, 0.6 ms; 40 axial slices; phase-encoding direction, posterior-to-anterior; FA, 80°; FOV, 224×224 mm; 244 volumes. In addition, a pair of spin-echo EPIs (TR/TE, 2000/25 ms; the same voxel size as the gradient-echo EPI with opposite phase-encoding directions) was acquired for distortion correction.

sec.title: Lesion segmentation
sec.p: Stroke lesions were manually segmented on T1W and T2W images in combination with clinical diffusion-weighted and fast-fluid-attenuated inversion recovery images or computed tomography. The comments on clinical MRI or computed tomography by radiologists were used as references for stroke lesions.

sec.title: Preprocessing
sec.p: Anatomical and resting-state fMRI data were preprocessed and registered into the template space of the MNI152NLin6Asym at a 2 mm isotropic resolution using fMRIprep12 ver.22.1.1. During the preprocessing of functional images, EPIs were corrected for slice timing, head motion, and susceptibility distortion. If the head motion during the resting-state fMRI scans was >1 mm, data from the participants were excluded from further analysis. To obtain magnetization stabilization during the gradient-echo EPI scans, the initial four scans were discarded prior to further analysis. Artefacts and nuisance signals were removed from the EPIs by automated classification of independent components estimated using the FMRI Software Library’s13 ICA-based Xnoiseifier (FIX).14 We used the default FIX threshold.

sec.title: Functional connectivity analysis
sec.p: Functional connectivity was obtained from the covariance matrices. BOLD time series data were extracted from the denoised resting-state fMRI data in 39 regions of interest based on the multi-subject dictionary learning atlas.15 Additionally, they were standardized using NiftiMapsMasker imported from “nilearn.maskers” in Nilearn ver.0.10.1. To address remaining structural noise after denoising with FIX, we regressed out confounders related to white matter and cerebrospinal fluid. Empirical covariance matrices were calculated using EmpiricalCovariance imported from “sklearn.covariance” in scikit-learn ver.1.3.2.

In the graphical lasso algorithm, a sparse inverse covariance matrix can be estimated using regularization based on the ℓ1 norm of the inverse covariance matrix Ω. This is expressed by the following equation:9

where is the sample covariance matrix, and λ is a regularization parameter. By developing the algorithm using group data, the GSIC matrices were estimated with regularization based on the mixed norm ℓ21 using the following equation:11

where Ω(s) is the inverse covariance matrix for subject s in the population of S subjects. This group-sparse modelling was performed using GroupSparseCovarianceCV imported from “nilearn.connectome” in the Nilearn. The optimal regularization parameter λ was determined by cross-validation. The estimated GSIC matrices were negated to obtain partial correlations, which inferred the direct connections between the nodes.16

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Correlations between RCPM scores (range: 0-36) and functional connectivity from two sets of covariance matrices (empirical covariance matrices and the negative GSIC matrices) were assessed using Pearson’s correlation coefficients. To examine the potential effects of groups on the scores of the three sets and on lesion locations and volumes, a data-driven clustering analysis of functional connectivity and RCPM scores was performed using k-means clustering in MATLAB R2023a (The MathWorks, Inc., USA). Because patients with stroke in post-acute rehabilitation are usually divided into three groups based on their activities of daily living: those who need minimum assistance, those who need moderate assistance, and those who need total assistance, we set k=3. Clustering optimization was assessed using silhouette analysis.

Between-group differences in age, time from stroke onset, strength of connectivity, and RCPM scores were analyzed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) or Kruskal-Wallis Test using MATLAB or R ver.3.6.3 (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria; URL https://www.R-project.org/), depending on the normality of the data and equality of distributions. Fisher’s Exact Tests evaluated associations between group and sex or stroke type.

The nonparametric analysis of longitudinal data in a factorial design was performed using nparLD17 in R software packages to determine whether there were significant interactions between the group and the RCPM set on the scores. Furthermore, a one-way repeated measures ANOVA or nonparametric analysis of longitudinal data was performed to determine whether there were significant intragroup differences in the scores of the three sets.
Lesion locations were analyzed using the center of mass, calculated with Analysis of Functional NeuroImages18 3dCM. Lesion volumes were compared between groups using one-way ANOVA.

Spearman’s rank correlation assessed relationships between the RCPM scores and time taken to solve RCPM tasks to estimate cognitive effort. In all analyses, statistical significance was set at P<0.05, with Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons.

sec.title: Functional connectivity estimated using network modelling of resting-state fMRI data
sec.p: Resting-state functional connectivity was assessed using a connectome-based analysis (Figure 1). Compared with the empirical covariance matrix (Figure 1A), the GSIC matrix (Figure 1B) and the negative GSIC matrix (Figure 1C) exhibited a qualitatively “shrunken or sparse-induced” effect on the connectivity between regions of interest. Notably, certain connections appeared to have greater contrast in the GSIC matrix and the negative GSIC matrix.

caption.p: —Functional connectivity estimated using network modelling of resting-state fMRI data. A) Example of an empirical covariance matrix computed from resting-state fMRI signals across 39 regions of interest using the multi-subject dictionary learning atlas.15 The top-right inset shows the corresponding graph on an axial slice (edge threshold, 90%); B) group-sparse inverse covariance (GSIC) matrix estimated using the same fMRI signals as in panel A). The top-right inset shows the corresponding graph on an axial slice (edge threshold, 90%). C) Negative GSIC matrix obtained by negating the GSIC matrix (B) to estimate interregional partial correlations. The top-right inset shows the corresponding graph on an axial slice (edge threshold, 90%). All figures share the same color scale (-1 to 1).

sec.title: Correlations between connectivity in the negative GSIC matrices and RCPM scores
sec.p: No significant correlation was observed between connectivity in the empirical covariance matrices and the RCPM scores. However, in the negative GSIC matrices, a significant inverse correlation was identified between connectivity of the posteromedial (Dors PCC) and the left inferior parietal cortex (L Par) and the scores (r=-0.53, P=0.023; Figure 2A-C). This suggests that increased left mediolateral parietal connectivity may reflect poorer visuospatial analogical reasoning performance in patients with stroke.

caption.p: —Correlations between connectivity in the negative GSIC matrices and RCPM scores. A) Pearson’s correlation coefficients between negative GSIC matrix connectivity and RCPM scores. The top-right inset shows the corresponding graph on an axial slice (edge threshold, 90%). B) P values corrected for multiple comparisons for these correlations. C) 3D brain visualization of connectivity showing a significant inverse correlation with scores. L Par: left inferior parietal cortex; Dors PCC: posteromedial parietal cortex; A: anterior; P: posterior; S: superior; I: inferior; L: left; R: right.

sec.title: Characterization of RCPM scoring patterns across groups
sec.p: Silhouette coefficients were 0.76, 0.75, 0.73, 0.73, and 0.73 for k=2, 3, 4, 5, and 6, respectively, suggesting that the optimal clustering was obtained when k=2. However, we set k=3 instead of 2 because the small number of clusters (k=2) may not capture the clinical levels of daily living activities, and the coefficient of 0.75 for k=3 was reasonably high. Thus, patients were divided into three groups (1, 2, and 3) based on their RCPM scores and parietal connectivity strength using k-means clustering (Figure 3A). Groups 2 and 3 were significantly older than group 1 (Table I).

caption.p: —Characterization of RCPM scoring patterns across groups. A) Scatterplot of RCPM scores vs. functional connectivity between Dors PCC and L Par in negative GSIC matrices, with group 1 (dark blue triangles), group 2 (silver circles), and group 3 (red triangles); B) mean functional connectivity between Dors PCC and L Par by group, with error bars indicating standard error; C) box and whisker plots showing RCPM scores by group (maximum, upper quartile, median, lower quartile, and minimum); D) Histograms of scores for RCPM sets A, Ab, and B across groups. *P<0.05, ***P<0.001. RCPM, Raven’s Colored Progressive Matrices; L Par, left inferior parietal cortex; Dors PCC, posteromedial parietal cortex.

caption.title: —Characteristics of the groups determined by the clustering.

table-wrap-foot.p: *P=0.046, Group 1 vs. Group 2; ***P<0.001, Group 1 vs. Group 3

sec.p: Significant intergroup differences in both connectivity and scores were observed (connectivity: F(2,55)=10.71, P<0.001; scores: Kruskal-Wallis χ2=50.67, df=2, P<0.001; Fig. 3B, C). Post-hoc tests revealed that connectivity was significantly higher in groups 2 (P=0.018) and 3 (P<0.001) compared to group 1 (Figure 3B). Scores were significantly lower in groups 2 and 3 than in group 1 (P<0.001 for both), with group 3 scoring significantly lower than group 2 (P<0.001) (Figure 3C). This analysis confirms that increased connectivity correlates with poorer performance across groups.

Significant effects of group and RCPM set were found on scores (group: ANOVA-type static=214.38, df=1.96, P<0.001; set: ANOVA-type static=34.37, df=1.96, P<0.001), along with a significant interaction between group and set (ANOVA-type static=2.49, df=3.71, P=0.045). Therefore, we examined whether there were significant intragroup differences in the scores of the three sets (Figure 3D). Further analysis revealed significant differences in scores between sets within each group (group 1: ANOVA-type static=8.21, df=1.79, P<0.001; group 2: F(2,38)=19.11, P<0.001; and group 3: F(2,32)=11.50, P<0.001). In all groups, scores for set B were significantly lower than for set A (group 1, P=0.031; group 2, P<0.001; group 3, P<0.001). In groups 1 and 2, scores for set Ab were significantly higher than for set B (group 1, P<0.001; group 2, P<0.001) but not significantly different from set A (group 1, P=0.725; group 2, P=0.999). Conversely, in group 3, scores for set Ab were significantly lower than those for set A (P=0.021). These findings highlight a unique low-scoring pattern for set Ab in group 3, associated with the highest parietal connectivity (Figure 3B) and poorest performance (Figure 3C).

sec.title: Lesion probability mapping across groups
sec.p: Lesion probability maps revealed the centers of lesions in each group (Figure 4A-C). Groups 1 and 2 had lesions centered in the right thalamus (group 1: x=20.9, y=-13.7, z=9.7; group 2: x=8.8, y=-15.0, z=10.9; Figure 4A, B), while group 3 had lesions centered in the left genu of the internal capsule (x=-17.2, y=-7.1, z=11.8; Figure 4C). None of these lesions affected the posteromedial and left inferior parietal cortices. No significant differences in lesion volumes were found among groups (F(2,55)=0.02, P=0.981; Figure 4D).

caption.p: —Lesion probability mapping across groups. A) Probability map of stroke lesions (N.≥2) for group 1; B) probability map of stroke lesions (N.≥2) for group 2; C) probability map of stroke lesions (N.≥2) for group 3. Intersections of green lines mark the center of mass for each group’s lesions. A: anterior; P: posterior; S: superior; I: inferior; L: left; R: right. Color bars denote patient count. D) Mean lesion volumes across groups, with error bars showing standard error.

sec.title: Relationship between RCPM scores and time for problem solving
sec.p: A significant inverse correlation was identified between scores and the time taken to solve the RCPM (r=-0.53, P<0.001; Figure 5). This suggests that greater cognitive demand may be required to solve the RCPM as performance declines.

caption.p: —Relationship between RCPM scores and time for problem solving. Scatterplots showing the relationship between RCPM scores and solving time. Group markers: dark blue triangles (group 1), silver circles (group 2), and red triangles (group 3).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We investigated the relationship between higher-order visuospatial function, as measured by the RCPM, and the covariance structures of spontaneous brain activity after stroke using connectome-based behavior mapping and data-driven patient clustering. A data-driven fMRI-based connectome analysis enabled us to explore previously unknown connectivity patterns relevant to higher-order visuospatial function after stroke. Connectome-based mapping revealed a significant inverse correlation between higher-order visuospatial performance and mediolateral parietal connectivity. Data-driven clustering further demonstrated that the group with the highest parietal connectivity exhibited a distinct low-scoring pattern. These findings deepen our understanding the neural substrates underlying higher-order cognitive function and highlight the potential value of neuroimaging for characterizing post-stroke cognitive impairment.

A previous neuroimaging study in healthy individuals has shown that the prefrontal cortex is engaged during visuospatial analogical reasoning.19 Additionally, the bilateral inferior parietal cortex was also active during these tasks.19 In this study, left mediolateral parietal connectivity, estimated using group-sparse modelling (Figure 1), was inversely correlated with visuospatial analogical reasoning performance in patients with stroke (Figure 2). Specifically, as connectivity increased, performance worsened (Figure 3A-C), which was similar in patients with multiple sclerosis.20 To further investigate, we analyzed the scoring patterns across patient subgroups determined by data-driven clustering.

A notable finding was the shift to a low-scoring pattern in set Ab, observed only in group 3 (Figure 3D). The sets A, Ab, and B of the RCPM are designed to progressively increase in difficulty, with set Ab requiring participants to integrate discrete figures into organized whole.5 Group 3’s difficulty with set Ab suggests impaired analogical reasoning involving discrete spatial entities. This distinct low-scoring distribution may reflect severe deficits in reasoning though visuospatial analogy in patients with increased parietal connectivity.

Lesion mapping indicated that the center of lesions in group 3 was localized in the left genu of the internal capsule, unlike those in the right thalamus in groups 1 and 2 (Figure 4A-C). Previous studies have demonstrated the dominance of the left hemisphere in abstract thinking, complex problem-solving, and error correction strategies.6, 7, 21 Additionally, previous studies using lesion-symptom mapping have shown regions implicated in cognitive impairments, such as the left posteroinferior parietal cortex, left basal ganglia, left frontotemporal lobes, left thalamus, and the right parietal lobe.22, 23 Our findings align with this evidence, supporting the observed deficits in RCPM performance in group 3. Importantly, lesion volume did not differ significantly among the groups (Figure 4D).

The regions implicated in parietal connectivity have distinct roles: the posteromedial parietal cortex (Dors PCC) is a highly connected cognitive hub with a high baseline metabolic rate,24-26 while the left inferior parietal cortex (L Par) is part of the attention network.27, 28 In this study, changes in functional connectivity involving the posteromedial and inferior parietal cortices were associated with visuospatial reasoning deficits. However, the prefrontal cortex, typically implicated in analogical reasoning,19 was not involved (Figure 2). Stroke-induced disruptions in top-down signaling could contribute to these findings. Our findings of the changes in connectivity were likely to come from indirect effects of lesions, as regions of parietal connectivity were spared from direct lesion effects (Figure 4).

Performance on the RCPM inversely correlated with time taken to solve the problems (Figure 5), indicating increased cognitive demand to extract spatial relations during analogies in patients with severe impairment. This process may involve the inferior parietal cortex.19 Therefore, it is possible that the inferior parietal cortex may need to be strongly and intrinsically coupled with the cognitive hub region, the posteromedial parietal cortex. This presumably occurs through compensatory mechanisms in response to cognitive demands but is insufficient to overcome performance deficits. While this interpretation is hypothetical, it aligns with evidence that increasing demand for orientation-specific attention control are associated with greater activation in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, dorsal cingulate cortex, and parietal regions, including the inferior and posteromedial areas, in healthy individuals.29 Alternative interpretations of parietal connectivity are possible. Stroke-induced disruptions in the frontoparietal network can lead to maladaptive hyperconnectivity or compensatory strategies in the parietal cortex. Further studies using neuronal interventions, such as transcranial magnetic stimulation, will validate these interpretations.

The effect of ageing on RCPM scores5 was consistent with our findings of poorer and slower performance in the older groups (Figure 3C, D, Figure 5, Table I). In these groups, lower scores were accompanied by increased variability and effort during problem-solving (Figure 5), suggesting heterogeneous cognitive strategies even among patients achieving similar scores. Our connectivity analysis could distinguish older patients with pathologically effortful problem-solving strategies from those with less impaired cognitive function.

Correlation or covariance measures are commonly employed in resting-state fMRI studies to quantify connectivity. While simple correlation may inaccurately represent complex networks, partial correlation infers direct connections.16 Partial correlations can be calculated from the inverse of the covariance matrix. However, this approach is often unstable due to the high dimensionality of the data. Regularizing the inverse covariance matrix, such as with ℓ1-norm regularization,9 reduces noise by shrinking small, noisy entries to zero while refining the estimation (Figure 1). The GSIC approach enabled the identification of connectivity patterns underlying visuospatial reasoning deficits in patients with stroke, which were not detectable with empirical covariance calculations (Figure 2). The lower detectability with empirical covariance may result from reduced contrast in each patient’s connectivity matrix (Figure 1). These findings suggest that group-sparse modelling of the inverse covariance structure may be an effective method for identifying neural correlates of higher-order cognitive functions in stroke populations.

sec.title: Limitations of the study
sec.p: This study has several limitations. First, imaging data from patients with large lesions often failed preprocessing, limiting the participant pool to those with relatively small lesions. Second, the correlational nature of the study precludes conclusions about causal relationships between connectivity and performance. Future research employing connectivity-based interventions is necessary to address causality and further validate these findings.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In conclusion, residual mediolateral parietal connectivity may underlie visuospatial analogical reasoning in patients with stroke. Additionally, the distinct low-scoring distribution pattern observed in the group with the highest parietal connectivity highlights the severe impairment in reasoning through visuospatial analogy associated with increased connectivity. The integration of data-driven clustering with connectome-based fMRI offers a promising approach for identifying the neural correlates of higher-order visuospatial function and characterizing individual patients with post-stroke cognitive impairment.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors thank Mr. T. Fukuba and Mr. A. Iwase for their technical support with MRI and Canon Medical Systems for their assistance in developing the MRI used in this research.

fn.p: Conflicts of interest: The authors certify that there is no conflict of interest with any financial organization regarding the material discussed in the manuscript.
